Bluesky Thread: UBC FOI Deadline Violation & OIPC Complaint

POST 1 (Lead) THREAD: University of British Columbia violated BC Freedom of Information deadline (Nov 5) and admits records won’t be reviewed for “next few months” despite taking “under 3 hours” to gather.

Formal complaint filed with BC Information and Privacy Commissioner (OIPC) Nov 8.

Here’s why statutory deadlines matter:

POST 2 (Timeline basics) Timeline:

  • FOI request filed: August 2025
  • Application fee paid: September 22, 2025 ($10)
  • Statutory deadline: November 5, 2025 (30 business days)
  • Extension filed: None
  • Records reviewed: None

UBC’s own email confirmed: “The 30 working day deadline for responding to your request is now November 5, 2025.”

POST 3 (What was requested) Request subject: Records concerning UBC’s partnership (or lack thereof) with Dongguk University, South Korea.

Why it matters: Dongguk lists UBC as partner on their website. UBC doesn’t list Dongguk among Korean partners. Anonymous Canadian university confirmed no partnership exists with Dongguk.

Is UBC’s partnership real or false?

POST 4 (UBC’s admission - deadline violation) November 7, 2025: FOI Specialist Suzanne Raikes admitted:

“We are currently working through a substantial backlog of requests and have been unable to meet the deadlines specified by the FIPPA.”

Translation: UBC is systematically violating BC transparency law across multiple requests.

POST 5 (UBC’s admission - indefinite delay) More from UBC (Nov 7):

“At this stage, I have not reviewed any records that have been provided and do not anticipate that happening for the next few months.”

So: Deadline passed Nov 5. No review done. Won’t start for “months.”

When DO statutory deadlines apply?

POST 6 (The contradiction) Here’s the absurdity:

UBC confirmed no cost recovery fee needed because records “would be able to [be gathered] within three hours.”

So: gathering takes 3 hours, but reviewing won’t happen for months?

How does “backlog” justify ignoring legal deadlines for 3 hours of work?

POST 7 (Legal problem - backlog not valid excuse) Under BC FIPPA Section 10, public bodies can request extensions for:

  • Volume of records
  • Third-party consultations
  • Clarification needed

UBC admitted: “we do not believe that this request met the threshold for an extension.”

So why wasn’t deadline met?

POST 8 (Legal problem - no extension filed) Critical point: UBC knew they couldn’t meet deadline but filed NO extension request before Nov 5.

FIPPA requires extensions be requested BEFORE deadline. You can’t just ignore deadline and claim “backlog” after the fact.

That’s not how statutory obligations work.

POST 9 (Public interest context - partnership fraud) Why this request matters:

Dongguk University claims 5 Canadian university partnerships. We’ve verified 2 out of 5 (40%) are false or unverifiable:

  1. Anonymous Canadian university: confirmed no partnership, requested anonymity when speaking to media
  2. UBC: doesn’t list Dongguk, won’t verify (now violating FOI deadline)

POST 10 (Public interest context - student safety) Korean government research (KWDI 2020) found 61.5% of female students in arts/culture programs experience sexual violence, mostly perpetrated by male-dominated faculty.

Canadian students deserve verified partnerships before studying abroad. UBC’s FOI violation prevents verification.

POST 11 (Public interest context - systematic evasion) Same week UBC violated FOI deadline (Nov 5):

Embassy Seoul claimed “no record” of citizen’s email despite Message-IDs from two government servers proving delivery.

Two Canadian institutions avoiding accountability on Korea-related verification issues.

POST 12 (OIPC complaint filed) November 8, 2025: Formal complaint filed with BC Information and Privacy Commissioner (@oipcbc.bsky.social) under Section 52 of FIPPA.

Grounds:

  1. Statutory deadline violation (Section 7)
  2. No valid extension filed (Section 10)
  3. “Backlog” not valid legal excuse
  4. Indefinite delay without justification
  5. Failure to exercise duty to assist (Section 6)

POST 13 (What we’re asking OIPC) Relief requested from OIPC:

  1. Order UBC to comply immediately with specific timeline
  2. Review UBC’s FOI processes (systematic violations affecting all applicants)
  3. Issue findings on whether “backlog” excuses statutory violations
  4. Investigate if UBC is fulfilling FIPPA obligations

POST 14 (Broader implications) If major universities can ignore FOI deadlines by claiming “backlog,” what’s the point of having statutory transparency laws?

Every BC public body would just claim “backlog” and delay indefinitely.

OIPC intervention needed to preserve meaningful access to information.

POST 15 (Accountability matters) This isn’t just about one request. It’s about:

  • Whether BC public bodies comply with transparency law
  • Whether students can verify international partnerships before studying abroad
  • Whether institutional accountability exists when fraud is alleged

UBC has legal obligation to respond. “Backlog” doesn’t erase that.

POST 16 (Documentation) Full complaint documentation, UBC’s admissions, timeline, and analysis: https://blog.genderwatchdog.org/blog-seoulemb-denial-oct7-discrepancies/

Original .eml files (redacted for advocate safety): https://drive.proton.me/urls/NA8BDFKMG8#40TDPocrR5xH

OIPC complaint includes:

  • UBC’s emails admitting deadline violation
  • Fee payment confirmation
  • Request timeline
  • Public interest context

POST 17 (Closing) BC FIPPA creates statutory right to information from public bodies. UBC is taxpayer-funded.

When universities ignore legal deadlines for “months” while admitting records take “under 3 hours” to gather, OIPC oversight is essential.

Waiting for Commissioner’s review.

#Transparency #FOI #BCFIPPA #PublicAccountability
